Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History: Making a large impact on a small herbarium: Integration of un-accessioned and orphaned specimens to secure and promote wider use of the collection
Award.AbstractNarration:
Herbaria are irreplaceable repositories of botanical diversity that catalog the occurrence of plants in the past and present. These collections serve as a foundation in plant science and science policy, especially those serving rural communities. In this setting, herbaria are especially important data sources because land managers require information on native and introduced species, as well as the effects of rapidly changing species assemblages. While serving the larger scientific community, regional herbaria also serve local residents, farmers, private and government policy makers, and land managers more specifically and thoroughly. It is therefore vital that herbaria accurately represent the past and present plant diversity. The Georgia Southern University (GSU) Herbarium holds 21,127 catalogued specimens and is housed in a state-of-the-art building. However, an estimated 26,500 vascular plant specimens (55.6% of the collection) are unorganized and in need of curation and integration to fulfill their scientific value and use. Most of this un-accessioned material comes from the Georgian Coastal Plain, a relatively poorly sampled region that harbors many rare and endangered species. This award will allow GSU to integrate two recently acquired orphaned collections and other backlogged specimens, doubling the GSU Herbarium's holdings and assure the security of an invaluable scientific collection for future generations. Through this project, these specimens will be mounted onto herbarium sheets and data about the collections will be digitized, which will improve and secure the collection for research and education over the long-term. Furthermore, the facility will be updated with the necessary tools to provide researchers and students access to the most comprehensive collection of plant diversity in the region through loans, visits, and online databases.

The GSU Herbarium has 21,127 accessioned specimens, but an estimated 26,500 specimens documenting the regional diversity of southeastern Georgian Coastal Plain, including rare species, collections from sparsely sampled areas, and the orphaned Youth Museum of Savannah Herbarium and the Flora of Fort Stewart, are inaccessible for research and education. This impedes efforts to integrate contemporary collections, reorganize the collection, integrate nomenclatural changes, and other educational outreach initiatives, generating an urgent need to process the backlogged collection. The project will integrate un-accessioned specimens into the main collection by transferring collection book information into label data. Specimens will be mounted and filed, and the label data uploaded into existing online database repositories to increase their dissemination and use. In addition, reorganization and nomenclatural updates will secure the collection for future use and facilitate access. The award will greatly enhance and secure a unique, historically significant collection that documents the exceptional plant diversity of the Coastal Plain. Active-learning modules will be created to engage high school and freshman college students, while integrating STEM education. The award will further allow the Herbarium to engage and train GSU's diverse student community by participating in a mentored learning environment and gain experience crucial to pursuing STEM careers by actively assisting in curatorial practices. Results can be viewed on the GSU Herbarium's website (sites.google.com/a/georgiasouthern.edu/gasherbarium/home) and data will be shared and made available through iDigBio (www. idigbio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our society is entirely dependent on plants for natural resources and ecological health. Therefore, it is vital that we preserve, catalog, and understand our natural resources, as well as how plants interact with humans, animals, other plants, and the environment. Herbaria are libraries of plant species diversity that catalog plant species' occurrences in the past and present and play a central role in our understanding of plants. Like all natural-history collections, they serve as the foundation of biological science and science policy. Herbarium specimens are essential for classifying, identifying, discovering, and studying botanical diversity. The information they contain is irreplaceable and priceless because no other data source documents plant species and their attributes through time as accurately. Herbaria allow us to document important biological phenomena and address current societal challenges. Their use has allowed biologists to study, for example, population declines due to overharvesting, the effects of agriculture on crop species in their native ranges, the origins of crop species and the development of modern agricultural practices, pathogenicity and changes in pathogens and their hosts over time, environmental health, the ongoing consequences of gene flow during speciation, responses of flowering time to climate change, the movement of invasive species into new areas, and species distributions. Herbaria have also guided our science policy, for example, by allowing us to prioritize conservation strategies. Herbarium collections made in the past have been vital to answer questions in the future, even without knowledge of how they will be utilized when they were collected. Thus, our society may face many problems in the future whose solutions are housed in herbaria today. It is, therefore, critical that we maintain, grow, and protect herbaria. 

 

The purpose of the NSF funded project was to integrate the legacy and orphaned collections of the Georgia Southern University (GSU) Herbarium, Savannah Youth Museum Herbarium, and the Ft. Stewart collection into the main GSU Herbarium. The three collections, which included many endangered species and those that cannot be recollected because they were collected on historical sites that have since been modified, have been previously inaccessible and unknown to researchers. To achieve the project's main goal, 29,303 specimens were processed, the majority of which came from the Georgian Atlantic Coastal Plain, one of the most understudied, but botanically diverse, regions in the southeastern U.S. All data are now freely available to researchers and the public through the SERNEC data portal (http://sernecportal.org/portal/). In total, the GSU Herbarium doubled in size, which now provides society with a more realistic understanding of the Georgian Atlantic Coastal Plain plant diversity.

 

The majority of the work was conducted by students. Twenty undergraduate and four graduate students were employed. A major goal of our proposal was to provide students that come from traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) education a chance to gain experiences in botanical science. To meet this goal, we drew from Georgia Southern University's diverse student community. The student's early careers in STEM were therefore initiated, many of whom have already moved forward to the next step in their career.

 

Herbarium specimens are composed of a pressed plant mounted on archival-quality paper, along with a specimen label that documents what the species is, where and when it was collected, and who collected it. Properly stored herbarium specimens have lasted hundreds of years (specimens collected in 1532 persist today); making the preservation, storage, and protection of the specimens vital to their lasting impact on science and society. Curators store specimens in folders, which serve as the main way in which they are protected. A second goal of the grant was to replace ripped or otherwise degraded folders with archival-quality folders that are arranged geographically. The poor-quality folders, many of which were overstuffed, diminished the protective value that folders should provide, and put the collection at risk. While replacing folders, the collection was organized into colored folders based on where they were collected to ease searching for particular specimens from specific areas, updated their names, and arranged them according to evolutionary history.

 

Students visit natural history collections to learn about how specimens are generated, stored, and used, and how they are important to society. As part of this project, an exercise was developed to provide student visitors with a first-hand experience to see exactly why herbarium collections are so important. The exercise was designed to have students use the herbarium to ask and answer questions about the importance of species interactions. Natural history collections are inherently fascinating and visitors are interested in engaging in the material. By providing learning modules like the one developed for this project, curators can demonstrate exactly how natural history collections are fundamental to biological science and how collections can be used to answer important questions, thus maximizing student learning outcomes.
